Unveiling the crucial active sites responsible for CO, n-heptane, and toluene oxidation over Pt/ZrO2 catalyst Wen-Xia Zhang Writing – original draft Visualization Resources Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ a Xi Zhao Visualization Software Methodology Investigation b Lin-Ya Xu Visualization Software Resources Investigation Data curation b Shuang Xia Visualization Resources Investigation a Yu-Fen Zhou Visualization Software Investigation Formal analysis a Chong-Lai Chen Visualization Software Resources Investigation a Hai-Hua He Software Investigation Data curation a Meng-Fei Luo Supervision Project administration Conceptualization b Jian Chen Writing – review & editing Supervision Investigation Conceptualization ⁎ b a Jinhua Polytechnic, Jinhua 321007, People's Republic of China Jinhua Polytechnic Jinhua 321007 People's Republic of China aJinhua Polytechnic, Jinhua 321007, People's Republic of China b Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China Key Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces Institute of Physical Chemistry Zhejiang Normal University Jinhua 321004 China bKey Laboratory of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Catalysis Materials, Zhejiang Key Laboratory for Reactive Chemistry on Solid Surfaces, Institute of Physical Chemistry, Zhejiang Normal University, Jinhua 321004, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The surface Pt species and adsorbed oxygen on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst were successfully modulated by altering the preparation methods, resulting in distinct catalytic behaviors for CO, n-heptane, and toluene oxidation. The Pt/ZrO2 catalyst was initially prepared via wetness impregnation and subsequently reduced in an H2 atmosphere to obtain the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst. In contrast, the Pt/ZrO2-E catalyst was synthesized using ethanol solvent (also serving as a reducing agent) instead of water during wetness impregnation. Moreover, the pre-prepared Pt nanoparticles were loaded onto the ZrO2 surface using polyvinylpyrrolidine (as a protective and structure directing agent) dissolved in ethanol solvent to fabricate the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst. Among these catalysts, the Pt/ZrO2-R exhibits superior catalytic activity towards CO oxidation due to its abundant metallic Pt species. It is found that activity of Pt/ZrO2 catalyst for n-heptane oxidation is positively correlated with its surface adsorbed oxygen concentration, thus the highest activity is achieved over the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst possessing a higher concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen species. Unlike CO and n-heptane oxidation, toluene oxidation activity is affected by multiple factors, it is primarily promoted by synergistic catalysis between metallic Pt species (Pt0) and surface adsorbed oxygen species over the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst. Our preliminary findings underscore that precise modulation of sensitive active sites on surfaces plays a critical role in specific catalytic reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Catalytic oxidation Pt/ZrO2 catalyst Pt chemical state Surface adsorbed oxygen Synergistic catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are organic compounds with low boiling point and high saturated vapor pressure at room temperature, most VOCs have hydrocarbon, oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur elements, etc., which are very odorous and hazardous to the human [1–8]. Additionally, some VOCs would generate harmful secondary pollutants (eg. SOx, NOx) to global environment, such as causing photochemical smog and destroying the atmospheric ozone layer [9]. Nowadays, control of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission has been drawn more and more attentions due to the strict legislations published for protecting environment [10–12]. There are numerous technologies to control the VOCs emission, such as adsorption, membrane separation, thermal incineration, catalytic oxidation, low-temperature plasma, and photocatalytic oxidation. Among them, catalytic oxidation is widely recognized as one of the most efficient strategies for eliminating the dilute VOC (<0.5 vol%) in exhaust, which directly oxidizes VOCs into harmless CO2 and H2O at relatively low temperature [13,14]. Besides, catalytic oxidation also effectively deals with another common air pollutant CO which often exists in vehicle exhaust [15]. The oxidation efficiency and operation condition of catalytic oxidation is mainly dependent on the catalysts employed. The catalysts for VOCs oxidation can generally be classified into two categories: non-noble metal catalysts (Co3O4, MnOx, CuO) and noble metal catalysts (Pt, Pd, Ru) [16–20]. Considering the stability and oxidation activity, noble metal catalysts such as Pt based catalysts are regarded as one of the most promising catalysts for VOCs and CO oxidation. Recently, there are many works focusing on improving Pt based catalysts for catalytic oxidation of CO, and typical VOCs such as toluene [21–23]. Shi et al. prepared a ultra-low Pt loading (0.06 wt%) single-atom Pt-CeO2/Co3O4 catalyst exhibiting very high activity for toluene oxidation due to abundant Pt0, Ce3+ and Co3+ species on surface [24]. Pt nanoparticles size also affects the catalyst activity, Peng et al. found that controlling the balance of Pt dispersion and oxygen vacancy concentration of ceria leads to the highest oxidation activity of toluene oxidation over Pt/CeO2 catalyst [25]. Du et al. employed 2D birnessite-MnO2 nanosheet for toluene oxidation, and it is found that oxygen vacancies is one of the critical reason for high activity of toluene oxidation [26]. The study of DFT calculation suggests that oxygen vacancies on Pd/CeO2 surface could decrease the energy barrier for CO catalytic oxidation [27]. Support may affect the oxidation reaction mechanism, and the critical active sites are different for CO oxidation on Pt/SnO2, Pt/TiO2, Pt/SiO2 and Pt/Al2O3 [28]. Our previous work investigated the platinum catalysts supported on metal oxide supports (CeO2-ZrO2, CeO2, ZrO2 and Al2O3) for ethyl acetate and toluene oxidation. It is found that ethyl acetate is mainly dependent on the oxygen vacancy density of Pt catalyst, whereas synergistic catalysis of Pt0 species and oxygen vacancies promotes the toluene oxidation over Pt catalyst [29]. Therefore, revealing the key active site for a specific catalytic reaction is of great importance for developing a efficient catalyst. In this work, we successfully tailored the Pt species and surface adsorbed oxygen on Pt/ZrO2 through various catalyst preparation methods. The prepared catalysts were employed for the oxidation of CO, n-heptane (with the same carbon number as toluene), and toluene, exhibiting distinct catalytic behaviors for each reaction. Through comprehensive characterizations, it is confirmed that the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst with a higher proportion of Pt0 species displayed superior activity in CO oxidation. Furthermore, the concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen proved decisive in n-heptane oxidation, while synergistic catalysis between Pt0 species and surface adsorbed oxygen played a critical role in toluene oxidation. This work provides profound insights into active site modulation on Pt-based catalysts for specific oxidation reactions. Experimental section Catalyst preparation The ZrO2 support was fabricated by calcining ZrOCO3 precursor (99 %, Shanghai Diyang Chemical Co., Ltd.) in muffle furance at 600 °C for four hours. Pt/ZrO2 catalyst was synthesized via traditional wetness impregnation method. In typical, ZrO2 support (1 g) was dispersed into deionized water (5 mL), and H2PtCl6 solution (0.002 gPt·mL−1, 5 mL, Sino Chemical Reagent co., LTD.) was dropped into the mixture at room temperature with stirring for two hours. Afterwards, the mixture was evaporated at 90 °C to power, and the obtained power was calcined at 500 °C in muffle furance under a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 for four hours, then the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst was obtained. For preparation of Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst, the as-prepared Pt/ZrO2 catalyst was reduced under H2 flow (5 %H2/ N2 balanced, 30 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 1 h. The Pt/ZrO2-E catalyst was prepared by the same method of Pt/ZrO2 catalyst, except replacing deionized water by ethanol as reducing agent. For preparation of the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst, 50 mg polyvinylpyrrolidone K30 (PVP, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co.,Ltd. A) as protective and structure directing agent was added and other process was same to that of the Pt/ZrO2-E catalyst. Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the Pt/ZrO2 catalysts were measured in a Bruker D8 diffractometer with the Cu Kα radiation, the operation condition: in 2θ range of 10–90°, 40 kV and 40 mA, scan speed of 12° min−1. N2 physisorption was performed on a BK 200C apparatus at 77 K to determine the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) surface area of the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst. Prior the test, the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst was degassed for four hours at 100 °C to remove the residuals in the pores and channels. CO chemisorption was conducted in a BELCAT II analyzer to measure the Pt dispersion. Prior the test, the catalyst was reduced under a mixture gas flow (5 %H2/N2 balanced) at 150 °C for one hour. Subsequently, the CO flow (5 %CO/N2 balanced) was pulsed into the II analyzer, the Pt dispersion was analyzed by CO uptake with the assumption of CO: Pt=1:1. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was performed on a JEOL JEM- 2100F instrument operating with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment was performed to study the reducibility of the catalyst. Prior the test, the catalyst was dried in oven at 100 °C for twelve hours. Afterwards, 50 mg of catalyst was put into a tubular quartz reactor (i.d.= 6 mm, in.) and heated from room temperature to 800 °C with heat rate of 20 °C/min−1 in H2 mixture flow (5 % H2 /N2 balanced, 30 mL min−1). Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectra of CO chemisorption of these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts were collected on a Thermo-Fisher Nicolet iS50 FT-IR spectrometer which is equipped with a MCT detector and a PIKE DRIFT accessory. Prior the test, the catalyst was treated in a flow (10 % O2/N2 balanced) at 300 °C for one hour to remove the residuals, then cooled to room temperature in a N2 flow (30 ml min−1). The catalyst was reduced in H2 mixture flow (5 % H2/N2 balanced) at 300 °C for 1 h. Afterwards, the catalyst was cooled down to room temperature and CO mixture (5 % CO/N2 balanced, 30 ml min−1) was flowed for 30 min. The DRIFT spectra of CO chemisorption was recorded after N2 flowing 30 min. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected in an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument equipped with Al Kα source (hv= 1484.6 eV) operated at 15 kV. Binding energies of all elements were calibrated by the containment carbon (C1s = 284.6 eV). Catalytic activity tests For n-heptane and toluene oxidation, the test was conducted in a home-made tubular quartz reactor (i.d.= 6 mm, in.). 50 mg of as-prepared catalyst (60–80 mesh) was put into the reactor and then heated to 500 °C with ramping rate of 10 °C/min. A glass bubble containing liquid toluene or n-heptane was cooled into a ice-water bath, the saturated steam of toluene or n-heptane from that glass bubble was diluted into concentration of 4000 ± 100 ppm by air flow. Afterwards, the mixture gas was flowed into the reactor with a mass space velocity of 80,000 ml gcat −1 h − 1. The concentration of toluene or heptane in the inlet and outlet gas were analyzed by online by a gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID). The conversion was calculated by the equation: C o n v e r s i o n = ( [ C ] i n − [ C ] o u t ) / [ C ] i n × 100 % where [C]in and [C]out were the inlet and outlet concentrations of toluene or heptane, respectively. For CO oxidation, a CO mixture gas (0.6 vol% CO + 0.6 vol% O2 + 98.8 vol% N2) was flowed through the reactor loading catalyst (50 mg, 60–80 mesh) under the mass space velocity of 80,000 ml gcat −1 h−1. CO concentration in the inlet and outlet gas were determined by gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a TCD detector. CO conversion was caculated by the following formula: C o n v e r s i o n = ( [ C ] i n − [ C ] o u t ) / [ C ] i n × 100 % where [C]in and [C]out were the inlet and outlet concentration of CO, respectively. Result and discussion General characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns and N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm curves of Pt/ZrO2, Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 24.4, 28.2, 31.5, 34.2, 35.3, 49.3 and 50.1° appear for all these ZrO2 supported catalysts (Fig. 1a), which are assigned to the monoclinic ZrO2 support (JCPDS No. 371,484). The characteristic diffraction peaks of PtOx or metallic Pt species are absent in these catalysts, indicating Pt species is highly dispersed in the catalysts. In Fig. 1b, all these catalysts display type Ⅲ isotherm curves, indicating their non-porous or macroporous structure. The BET surface areas measured by N2 adsorption are summarized in Table 1 , these values confirm that the support structure remains unchanged regardless of the different preparation methods employed for these catalysts. The CO chemical adsorption method was used to determine the dispersion of Pt on these catalysts, it is found that all the Pt/ZrO2 catalysts exhibit relatively close levels of Pt dispersion. The Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst shows slightly larger Pt nanoparticle size compared to the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst due to Pt species growth in reduction process. And the Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts also show slightly larger Pt nanoparticle than that of Pt/ZrO2 catalyst due to different preparation method. Figs. 2 and 3 show the HRTEM images of the Pt/ZrO2, Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts to observe the Pt species distribution on ZrO2. The lattice fringe with inter-planar of 0.266 nm can be clearly observed, which is assigned to the facet of (100) PtO2 species. Fig. 3 shows the mean size of Pt species on the ZrO2 surface. It can be seen that the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst gives the smallest Pt nanoparticles. The Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts show comparable mean size of Pt nanoparticles. Such result suggests preparation method would slightly lead to the change of Pt nanoparticles, and the H2 reduction for Pt/ZrO2 also results in growth of Pt nanoparticles. Fig. 4 displays the DRIFT spectra of CO adsorption on Pt/ZrO2, Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts. After H2-reduction pre-treatment, oxidized Pt species can become metallic Pt0 species, and all these catalysts show a vibration peak at 2067 cm−1 which is ascribed to the linearly adsorbed CO on Pt0 species [30].Besides, a weak vibration peak appearing at 1826 cm−1 can be assigned to bridged adsorption CO on Pt0 species [31]. Compared to the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst, the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst shows both weaker vibration peak at 2067 and 1826 cm−1, which may be ascribed to the Pt particle slight growth during Pt/ZrO2-R preparation. The Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst with dark colour may be responsible for its weakest vibration peak. Fig. 5 displays H2-TPR profiles of Pt/ZrO2, Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts to study their reducibility. There are two reduction peaks at 325 and 710 °C observed for the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst, which are ascribed to reduction of PtOx and bulk ZrO2, respectively [32]. Compared to the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst, the reduction peak at 325 °C becomes slightly weak due to less PtOx after reduction pre-treatment in preparation. This result also indicates that the reduced Pt specie in Pt/ZrO2 would be easily oxidized due to exposure in air. A new peak centered at 450 °C is attributed to the surface ZrO2 reduction caused by H2-spillover in the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst, which temperature is much lower than that of bulk ZrO2 reduction. The Pt/ZrO2-E shows very strong reduction of PtOx at 325 °C, suggesting its high ratio of oxidized Pt specie. The reduction peaks of surface ZrO2 caused by H2 spillover and bulk ZrO2 are also observed for the Pt/ZrO2-E. Whereas, the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst shows only remarkable reduction of bulk ZrO2, the reduction peaks of PtOx and surface ZrO2 are very weak. To investigate the surface Pt species state, Fig. 6 shows the Pt 4f and O 1 s XPS spectra of Pt/ZrO2, Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2-EP catalysts. The component with binding energy at 71.0, 72.4 and 74.7 eV is assigned to the Pt 4f7/2 of Pt0 species, Pt2+ species and Pt4+species, respectively [33,34]. And the component with binding energy at 74.5, 75.9 and 78.2 eV is attributed to Pt 4f5/2 of Pt0, Pt2+ and Pt4+species, respectively [35–36]. In addition, the relative content of these Pt species (Pt0, Pt2+ and Pt4+) is analyzed by fitting the XPS spectra peak area as summarized in Table 1. Pt0 species relative content in these catalysts is in order of Pt/ZrO2-R>Pt/ZrO2-EP >Pt/ZrO2>Pt/ZrO2-E. Among them, the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst has the highest Pt0 species of 54.8 % due to the reduction treatment, whereas the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst shows the lowest Pt0 species of 8.6 %. These results certainly confirm that surface Pt species chemical state is heavily dependent on the preparation process. Besides, the oxygen specie of catalysts is also studied by analyzing the O1s spectra. The O 1 s XPS spectra of these catalysts have been deconvoluted into two components, namely the component with binding energy at 529.7 and 531.6 eV is ascribed to ZrO2 lattice oxygen Oa and surface adsorbed oxygen Ob (related to oxygen vacancies), respectively [37,38]. The concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen in these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts can be caculated by O 1 s XPS spectra and listed in Table 1. Considering that surface adsorbed oxygen is widely recognized as the critical active sites for the oxidation reaction, further investigation into the surface adsorbed oxygen on these catalysts was conducted through O2-TPD experiments in Fig. 7 . The desorption peak of O2 below 300 °C can be attributed to active surface adsorbed oxygen, while the peak above 300 °C is associated with relatively non-active surface oxygen species [39]. It can be found that intensity of active oxygen desorption peak decreases in order of Pt/ZrO2-EP > Pt/ZrO2-R > Pt/ZrO2-E > Pt/ZrO2, this trend aligns with that observed in XPS analysis of surface adsorbed oxygen (Table 1 and Fig. 6b). According to above results, it is confirmed that the surface absorbed oxygen concentration in these catalysts follows an order of Pt/ZrO2-EP > Pt/ZrO2-R > Pt/ZrO2-E > Pt/ZrO2. Catalytic oxidation of toluene, n-heptane and CO Fig. 8 shows the light-off curves and specific mass rate of CO, n-heptane and toluene oxidation over these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts. For the CO oxidation, the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst exhibits the lowest T99 of 160 °C among these catalysts, whereas the Pt/ZrO2, Pt/ZrO2-EP and Pt/ZrO2-E catalysts shows T99 near to 190 °C. At reaction temperature of 150 °C for CO oxidation, the specific mass rate is in order of Pt/ZrO2-R (2117 μmol gPt −1 s−1)> Pt/ZrO2-EP (670 μmol gPt −1 s−1)> Pt/ZrO2-E (358 μmol gPt −1 s−1)>Pt/ZrO2 (198 μmol gPt −1 s−1). For the n-heptane oxidation, the catalytic activity order is slightly different from that of CO oxidation, namely, specific mass rate at 140 °C in order of Pt/ZrO2-EP (1376 μmol gPt −1 s−1)>Pt/ZrO2-R (1218 μmol gPt −1 s−1)> Pt/ZrO2-E (1083 μmol gPt −1 s−1)>Pt/ZrO2 (1004 μmol gPt −1 s−1). For toluene oxidation, it is found that T99 of toluene oxidation over Pt/ZrO2-EP, Pt/ZrO2-R, Pt/ZrO2-E and Pt/ZrO2 catalysts is 150, 160, 190 and 210 °C, respectively. The specific mass rate at 80 °C for toluene oxidation is in order of Pt/ZrO2-EP (1743 μmol gPt −1 s−1) > Pt/ZrO2-R (717 μmol gPt −1 s−1)> Pt/ZrO2-E (659 μmol gPt −1 s−1) > Pt/ZrO2 (454 μmol gPt −1 s−1). Based on the above results, these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts show very different activity orders for CO, n-heptane and toluene oxidation, which should be closely related to the chemical state of Pt species and active oxygen species. Discussion Due to the presence of various VOC components in the exhaust gas, it is imperative to identify the surface active sites for specific oxidation reactions. Consequently, the contribution of surface active sites in these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts can be differentiated in following. For CO oxidation, the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst exhibits significantly higher activity compared to the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst. This discrepancy can be attributed to their substantial difference in relative content of surface Pt0 species (54.8% vs 24.5 %). Furthermore, there is a strong correlation between the catalytic activity order for CO oxidation and the ratio of surface Pt0 species in these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts, namely: Pt/ZrO2-R > Pt/ZrO2-EP > Pt/ZrO2-E >Pt/ZrO2. The presence of Pt0 species plays a critical role in CO and gaseous oxygen absorption and activation during CO oxidation, which has also been discussed in previous studies [40]. Therefore, it can be inferred that surface Pt0 species are dominant active sites for CO oxidation on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst. However, there is a very different trend observed for n-heptane oxidation compared to CO oxidation among these catalysts. Specifically, while the advantage of absolute high activity seen with the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst for CO oxidation diminishes; conversely, it is observed that the highest activity for n-heptane oxidation occurs with the use of the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst. The superior performance exhibited by the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst for n-heptane oxidation can be attributed to its highest content of surface absorbed oxygen species. The order of activity increase among these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts for n-heptane oxidation is positively correlated with the relative content of surface absorbed oxygen, suggesting that n-heptane oxidation over the Pt/ZrO2 catalysts is strongly dependent on the surface absorbed oxygen content. However, there is a distinct variation in the activity order for toluene oxidation over these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts. The Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst demonstrates an absolute advantage in terms of high activity for toluene oxidation compared to others. Considering the results pertaining to Pt0 species and surface adsorbed oxygen concentration on these catalysts, it can be inferred that neither single Pt0 species nor surface absorbed oxygen species alone play a decisive role in toluene oxidation. Evidently, multiple factors influence toluene oxidation on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst, Scheme 1 including the chemical state of Pt species, particle size of Pt species, and surface adsorbed oxygen concentration. Based on analysis of surface species present on these Pt/ZrO2 catalysts, it is deduced that the catalytic reaction involving toluene oxidation necessitates synergistic action between Pt0 and adsorbed oxygen, and slightly larger Pt species may facilitate better adsorption and activation of the aromatic ring in toluene. Conclusion In summary, various methods have been employed to prepare the Pt/ZrO2 catalysts in order to adjust the chemical state of surface Pt species and active oxygen species. These as-prepared Pt/ZrO2 catalysts were utilized for catalyzing CO, n-heptane, and toluene oxidation reactions. It is observed that different preparation methods significantly influence the chemical valence and particle size of Pt species, as well as the adsorption of oxygen on the catalyst surface. For instance, reduction pre-treatment results in a higher proportion of Pt0 species on the surface of Pt/ZrO2 catalysts, which plays a crucial role in CO oxidation reaction. In contrast, n-heptane oxidation activity is closely related to the concentration of adsorbed oxygen on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst surface. Different from the previous two oxidation reactions, toluene oxidation is influenced by multiple factors including synergistic catalysis between Pt0 species and adsorbed oxygen species, where larger particle sizes of Pt favored aromatic ring adsorption and activation. coredata.dc:description: The surface Pt species and adsorbed oxygen on the Pt/ZrO2 catalyst were successfully modulated by altering the preparation methods, resulting in distinct catalytic behaviors for CO, n-heptane, and toluene oxidation. The Pt/ZrO2 catalyst was initially prepared via wetness impregnation and subsequently reduced in an H2 atmosphere to obtain the Pt/ZrO2-R catalyst. In contrast, the Pt/ZrO2-E catalyst was synthesized using ethanol solvent (also serving as a reducing agent) instead of water during wetness impregnation. Moreover, the pre-prepared Pt nanoparticles were loaded onto the ZrO2 surface using polyvinylpyrrolidine (as a protective and structure directing agent) dissolved in ethanol solvent to fabricate the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst. Among these catalysts, the Pt/ZrO2-R exhibits superior catalytic activity towards CO oxidation due to its abundant metallic Pt species. It is found that activity of Pt/ZrO2 catalyst for n-heptane oxidation is positively correlated with its surface adsorbed oxygen concentration, thus the highest activity is achieved over the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst possessing a higher concentration of surface adsorbed oxygen species. Unlike CO and n-heptane oxidation, toluene oxidation activity is affected by multiple factors, it is primarily promoted by synergistic catalysis between metallic Pt species (Pt0) and surface adsorbed oxygen species over the Pt/ZrO2-EP catalyst. Our preliminary findings underscore that precise modulation of sensitive active sites on surfaces plays a critical role in specific catalytic reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Unveiling the crucial active sites responsible for CO, n-heptane, and toluene oxidation over Pt/ZrO2 catalyst
